If you or a loved one are struggling with mental health and thoughts of suicide, help is available. Even if there isn't a student-focused hotline in your state, please call the national line at 1-800-273-8255. 

We are here to help. #SuicidePreventionWeek

A student‚Äôs access to high-quality mental health resources is just as imperative to their future as their own education is.

I‚Äôm proud to partner with @RepChrisStewart on this BIPARTISAN legislation to address the mental health crisis facing our children‚¨áÔ∏è
https://newman.house.gov/media/press-releases/reps-newman-and-stewart-introduce-bipartisan-bill-create-and-support-student

Today, I introduced legislation to ensure every state has direct student-based mental health hotlines like these.

The Bipartisan Student Mental Health Helpline Act of 2021 would provide states with funds so they can create FREE, confidential, 24/7 hotlines for our youth. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E-75QykX0B0heKs.jpg

Some states have created student-focused mental health helplines that are FREE, confidential, and provide 24/7 support.

On top of being accessible over several platforms (texting, social media), they have direct relationships w/ local schools so they can follow up w/ resources.

Far too many teenagers can't even find mental health care because of a lack of affordable providers.

In fact, more than a third receive mental health services only from their own schools. And this doesn't even begin to touch on the shortage of counselors in the education system.

I have been upfront about my own child's experience of severe depression and anxiety in high school. 

Our family was lucky and privileged enough to ensure she received the support she needed but for too many families, that's not nearly the same case.

Let's also look at how these rates change by demographic.

40% of LGBTQ+ youth have said they seriously considered suicide. 

The number of white children attempting suicide in the U.S. decreased from 1991 to 2017, while the number of Black children attempting suicide went up.

Suicide is the SECOND leading cause of death among people ages 10-24. From 2007 to 2018, suicide rates for Americans ages 10 to 24 rose by 57%.

On top of this, cases of depression and anxiety in youth also skyrocketed. And with the pandemic, rates have only gotten worse.
